#### Section 1: Nanofabrication: Mastering and replication
A logic circuit in a silicon integrated circuit (i.e., a
*microprocessor* or more generally a *microchip*) contains billions of
**transistors** (essentially tiny electrical switches). Groups of
transistors can be configured to perform complex calculations, and
groups of groups of groups (and so on) of transistors are responsible
for all of modern computation, the internet, wireless communication, and
artificially intelligent systems. All of this work is enabled by
processes known as **top-down micro- and nanofabrication**. These
processes use energetic beams of light and electrons to make patterns on
surfaces. These patterns are used to guide the deposition of atoms onto
or into the surface of semiconductor wafers (e.g., silicon) into
intricate patterns. These wafers are then diced up into microchips and
integrated into printed circuit boards, which together execute all the
operations of a computer. This chapter provides an introduction to
processes used in the semiconductor industry and in university
cleanrooms. For a video primer to this chapter, visit

>>>video(https://youtu.be/Bee9q6GLWSc)

Essentially every active component of your computer and smartphone---not
to mention the integrated circuits in your car, dishwasher, and
microwave---are made using manufacturing processes that fit under the
umbrella term of **microfabrication**. However, the components of these
integrated circuits (e.g., transistors, capacitors, and resistors) of
most of these devices have nanoscale dimensions, and thus it is more
appropriate to refer to the process as **nanofabrication**, and that is
the word we will use throughout the rest of this book. Nanofabrication
is a suite of tools for the manufacturing of nanostructures. It includes
tools for modifying or decorating materials, such as thin-film
deposition, etching, and ion implantation. However, simple modification
of materials is not enough. These modifications must be patterned in two
and three dimensions.[^12.1.1] Methods for doing so include techniques of
**mastering**---generating new patterns for the first time in a form
from which multiple copies can be made---and **replication**---the
processes for making these copies. We will explore these methods, in
turn, below.

### 12.1.1. Mastering

In digital technology, you may have heard the word "mastering" in
several familiar contexts. For example, remastering a classic movie or
album, or producing a master for a musical recording. What is being
referred to is the process of making a high resolution digital
representation of the content in a form from which it can be copied
multiple times, see Figure (12.1). A good example from analog technology
which dates back hundreds of years is the rubber stamp. Once inked, the
stamp can make many copies of an image before it eventually degrades. In
the case of technology from the last few decades, CDs, DVDs, and blu-ray
disks are a good example. Here, a master is made by **electron-beam
lithography**. This master contains raised structures called **relief
structures** which is pressed into hot plastic (polycarbonate, for CDs)
to create an **inverse replica** in the copy. This copy is then
metallized by **physical vapor deposition** of aluminum.

(Figure 12.1) 
>>>image(mastering.png.0)

The manufacturing of silicon microprocessors uses a similar concept,
except that many---up to fifty!---masters are used. In the case of
semiconductor manufacturing, the workhorse process of mastering is
called **electron-beam lithography (EBL)**. In EBL, a quartz disc
covered with a thin layer of chromium is coated with a thin layer of
light-sensitive polymer called an **electron-beam resist**.[^12.1.2] An
electron beam is used to draw patterns of lines and shapes into the
resist film. The film is then immersed in a **developer** solution,
which washes away the regions of the resist film that were either
exposed or unexposed to the electron beam. Then, the bare chromium in
the regions uncovered by the resist film are etched in an etchant
solution. This process reveals see-through regions in the pattern
defined by the electron beam. The substrate is then placed in a third
type of chemical bath, which removes the resist film everywhere else.
Now what we have is a **transparency mask**---a quartz film covered in
an opaque chromium film that has patterns defined by EBL.

### 12.1.2. Replication

It may seem tempting to use EBL as a tool for manufacturing. However,
there are two problems.

1.  It is slow

2.  The resolution is not good enough

For example, it may take several hours to produce a mask for one layer
of a microprocessor. Also, the patterns written into masks used in
semiconductor manufacturing are typically significantly larger than what
ends up in the final chip.[^12.1.3] It is just easier to produce and repair
larger masters.

So, instead of using EBL for replication---i.e., large-scale
manufacturing---a different process is used, called **photolithography**
(Figure (12.2)). Photolithography, meaning roughly "writing in stone
with light," is the basis of semiconductor manufacturing and arguably
the most sophisticated manufacturing process for any commercial product.
It produces hundreds or thousands of patterns per hour with error rates
on the order of one in a quadrillion. Conceptually, it is similar to the
processes that happen in a photographic development, i.e., in a
darkroom, except that the film negative (the "master\" in that case) is
replaced with the chromium mask produced by EBL. In photolithography, a
silicon wafer is coated with a photoresist and placed in a device called
an **exposure tool** or **stepper**. In this device, high energy light
(UV) is shone through the mask and focused down (reduced in area) using
a series of lenses onto the photoresist film. The resist film is
developed, leaving holes, though which materials can be deposited (i.e.,
ions or metals) or the underlying silicon substrate can be etched.

(Figure 12.2) 
>>>image(photolithography.png.0)

Photolithographic steppers are the keystone instruments used in
semiconductor manufacturing. The importance is reflected in their cost,
with a state of the art stepper running in the ballpark of \$10$^8$. It
takes several steps of photolithography to generate a pattern in a
microprocessor. For example, the first few steps might be used on the
bare silicon substrate to define the positions of the transistors.
Subsequent steps might be used to connect these transistors to one
another to generate **logic circuits**. Different areas on the same chip
will be responsible for different functions. When it is all said and
done, up to fifty layers may have been deposited.

[^12.1.1]: Have you ever seen microscope images of microprocessors that look
    like futuristic cities?

[^12.1.2]: See Chapter 6 for a discussion of positive-tone and negative-tone
    photoresists, which are similar to electron-beam resists.

[^12.1.3]: If you break open an integrated circuit and look at the
    microprocessor inside, it is really, really small.

You're on the right track! That's a good basic understanding of mastering and replication. The textbook section on "Mastering" provides more details. I encourage you to review that part for a more complete explanation, including examples like rubber stamps and CDs.

#### Section 2: Thin-Film Deposition
Nanofabrication---and microfabrication before it---is intimately tied to
technologies used to deposit thin films. A thin film is generally
considered to be a uniform sheet of material with a thickness of 1$\mu$m
or less, though most are less than 100 nm. A thin film can be polymeric,
metallic, or ceramic, or particulate (e.g., a thin film of quantum
dots). Such films are either patterned using a scanning beam directly
(e.g., photoresist or electron-beam resist---often the same polymers can
be used for either purpose), or patterned by lift-off, in which one uses
a stencil mask with openings. The method of depositing the thin film
depends on the type of material being deposited and whether or not any
materials already present on the substrate are sensitive to the
conditions used to deposit the film.

### 12.2.1. Spin coating

Spin coating is a process by which a liquid precursor is deposited on a
flat substrate. The substrate must be globally planar, but can have
small relief structures that jut out at most a few hundred nanometers
from the plane of the surface. In semiconductor manufacturing, the
substrate is a **silicon wafer** with a diameter up to 18 inches or
more. In research on solar cells, the substrate is often a glass slide
cut into squares with sides of 1 inch each. The substrate is placed on a
**vacuum chuck** which sucks it down without the need for physical
clamps, which could damage the substrate. The experimenter---or an
automated tool---deposits a liquid precursor onto the substrate, such
that the liquid covers the substrate completely. The chuck and the
substrate are then spun around anywhere from 500 rpm to 10,000 rpm.

The liquid precursor is one of two things: a solution or liquid
prepolymer. If the precursor is a solution, which contains a polymer,
small molecule, or nanoparticles, the solvent evaporates and generates a
thin film of the solute. Incredibly, the resulting film is the same
thickness everywhere, except perhaps at the edges. The resulting
thickness depends on the concentration of the solute, the spin speed,
and the volatility of the solvent. The more concentrated, the thicker
the resulting film will be. The greater the spin speed, the more
material will be ejected from the substrate and thus the thinner the
film once solidified. The possibly counterintuitive determinant of
thickness is the volatility of the solvent (see Figure (12.3)). The
lower the boiling point, the quicker the solvent evaporates and the more
solid is left on the substrate. Once the solvent has evaporated, no more
material can be ejected from the spinning substrate, and the final
thickness does not change.

(Figure 12.3) 
>>>image(spin-coating.png.0)

In contrast, if the precursor is a liquid prepolymer, then the film gets
thinner and thinner as the sample continues to spin. That is, there may
be volatile components, but as long as the precursor is liquid, it will
be ejected with increased spin time. Greater spin speeds result in
thinner films. The major advantage of spin-coating is its simplicity and
the fact that it can be used for almost any material that can be
processed from a liquid precursor. One major disadvantage of
spin-coating is the relatively large amount of material that is ejected
from the spinning substrate. This stuff ends up on the interior walls of
the spin coater, and is difficult or impossible to recover.

Other methods of depositing solution-processible materials include
**spray deposition**, **slot-die coating** or **blade coating**---which
both operate through the process of **shear deposition**---and **dip
coating**, where one attaches a string to a substrate and draws it up
out of immersion in a solution at a controlled rate.

### 12.2.2. Physical vapor deposition

One of the most common forms of thin-film deposition is **physical vapor
deposition (PVD)** (Figure (12.4)). While PVD techniques involve
intimidating-looking vacuum chambers that may take up a significant
chunk of a room, they are ubiquitous and used in such mundane, low-cost
products such as potato chip bags (the aluminum coating used as a
barrier layer). There are three major types of PVD: (1) thermal
evaporation, (2) electron-beam evaporation, and (3) sputter deposition
(or coating). Each of these techniques deposits material atom by atom or
molecule by molecule and have a broad scope of applicable materials.
However, there are significant differences, which are highlighted where
appropriate.

(Figure 12.4) 
>>>image(PVD.png.0)

#### Thermal evaporation

Deposition by thermal evaporation is the process by which material is
raised to a high temperature under low pressure---e.g., 10$^{-6}$
torr---and redeposited on a substrate. In conventional thermal
evaporation, a material is heated resistively to white-hot temperatures
of a few thousand degrees celsius. The substrate is held several
centimeters above the evaporation source. This distance is smaller than
the **mean free path** of the evaporated flux of atoms at the base (low)
pressure. This setup ensures that evaporated atoms rarely collide with
ambient gas atoms, which would set them off course. The straight-line
trajectory of the evaporated atoms ensures that the thin films are
deposited in a **line-of-sight** manner. Thus, a **collimated**
(straight) beam deposits material like a flashlight, and creates shadows
where no material is deposited. Rotating the substrate in the chamber
can produce films with greater uniformity. At atmospheric pressure, the
mean free path of a gas molecule is about 70 nm. At 10$^{-7}$ torr, the
mean free path is greater than one meter---generally larger than the
dimensions of a PVD chamber.

#### Electron-beam evaporation

A related technique to thermal evaporation is **electron-beam thermal
evaporation** or just **electron-beam evaporation** or just **e-beam
evaporation**. This technique is similar to conventional thermal
evaporation except that instead of being heated resistively---i.e., by
sending a large current at a high voltage through a metal boat
containing the sample to be evaporated---a high energy beam of electrons
is emitted from a tungsten filament toward the evaporant held in a
graphite **crucible**, which is chilled by a recirculating water-based
chiller. This electron beam again causes the metal to heat up to (even
hotter!) white-hot temperatures. In e-beam evaporation, much higher
evaporation rates are possible (tens of nm per second or higher). The
system directs so much energy to the evaporant that a virtual source
forms a few centimeters from the real source, which is the source from
which the angles for line-of-sight deposition must be calculated. While
e-beam evaporation causes the evaporant sample to get hotter, faster,
and is amenable to a range of inorganic materials, it is incompatible
with structures that decompose upon exposure to cathode rays, such as
organic materials. For example, in the production of OLED displays,
conventional thermal evaporation is used, and the pixels are defined by
using a stencil mask.

#### Sputter deposition

The final category of physical vapor deposition is **sputter
deposition**. In this technique, a thick, circular (i.e., a short
cylindrical) puck or **target** is placed in a device called a sputter
gun. This apparatus is found in a vaccuum chamber, which is evacuated
and backfilled with a small amount of an inert gas, such as argon. The
sputter gun generates radio frequency radiation that ionizes the ambient
gas. These ions of this **plasma** collide with the metallic or ceramic
sputter target. The collisions between the ions and the sputter target
eject atoms from the target, which are accelerated toward the substrate.
Multiple guns can be placed in the chamber and activated simultaneously
to generate alloys and composite structures. In contrast to thermal and
e-beam evaporation, sputter deposition works even with relatively high
pressures (though still much lower than atmospheric pressure). This
increased pressure reduces the mean free path of sputtered atoms and can
reduce collimation. Thus, it is possible to achieve greater
conformability of the deposited films. Sputter deposition is the method
of choice for coating samples for **scanning electron microscopy
(SEM)**. It is also used widely in manufacturing of highly mundane
products, such as the aluminum foil coating in potato chip bags.

#### Structure of PVD-deposited thin films

The morphologies of PVD-deposited thin films differ markedly from those
of single crystalline or polycrystalline samples. For example, it is not
uncommon to observe a columnar morphology in a PVD-deposited film, where
the crystallites are stacked like columns of coins perpendicular to the
plane of the film. Another characteristic of PVD-deposited films is the
small size of the grains (i.e., crystallites) and the high density of
dislocations within them. This arrangement has a profound effect on the
mechanical behavior of thin films, see Figure (12.5).

(Figure 12.5) 
>>>image(dislocation.png.0)

Since plastic flow, responsible for the metallic properties ductility
and malleability, depends on the mobility of dislocations, any
microscopic mechanism that impedes the movement of dislocations would
also tend to resist deformation of the bulk material. Two of the ways in
which the mobility of dislocations is decreased is

1.  The density of dislocations---i.e., the energetic barrier for a
    dislocation to move in a zone that already has a lot of them is
    increased.

2.  The size of the grains and thus the number of grain
    boundaries---i.e., it is difficult for a dislocation to cross a
    grain boundary.

Thus, both characteristics of PVD-deposited films have the effect of
hindering the flow of dislocations, inhibiting plastic flow, and thus
hardening and embrittling the material. The same approach has been used
historically in the field of **metalworking**, in which hammered or
drawn metal has increased strength compared to the pristine material.

### 12.2.3. Equipment for PVD

#### Vacuum chambers

Most PVD operations must be carried out in a vacuum chamber capable of
maintaining pressures of \<10$^{-6}$ torr. Critically, every component
must be sealed with the appropriate gaskets, and electrical connections
must be soldered or passed through with the appropriate hardware.
Replacement of valves, pumps, and removal of viewing portals or other
components generally requires a new copper gasket or Viton o-ring every
time it is performed. Chilled water is often used in thermal and e-beam
evaporators to prevent the hearth from overheating and possibly melting.
Needless to say, the inlet and outlet lines must be tightened
appropriately.[^12.2.1] Typically, water lines and chamber doors use
elastomeric o-rings and circular portals and joints use copper gaskets.

#### High vacuum pumps

If the heart of a PVD system is the hearth where the sample is heated,
the lungs are the vacuum equipment. Most high-vacuum systems have two
functions for pumps, and thus two different kinds of pumps: a **roughing
pump** and a **high-vacuum pump**. Figure (12.6) The roughing pump is
usually a rotary-vane or direct-drive pump which is required because a
high-vacuum pump generally cannot be exposed to atmospheric pressure,
due to saturation of the adsorbant or overheating of the components.
Once the roughing pump is used to achieve a sufficiently low pressure
(ca. 10$^{-3}$ torr), you close the valve to the roughing pump and open
the valve to the high-vacuum pump (or turns on the high-vacuum pump in
the case of diffusion pumps, which are always connected to the roughing
pump). High-vacuum pumps use a few different mechanisms: **oil
diffusion**, **cryogenic**, and **turbomolecular**.

(Figure 12.6) 
>>>image(pumps.png.0)

An oil diffusion pump---or **momentum transfer pump**---uses a heating
element to vaporize a high molecular weight oil in a reservoir. The oil
molecules travel up a jet-like column housed in an open cylinder with an
array of baffles arranged from top to bottom, each larger than the
previous, like a Christmas tree. The gas molecules are deflected toward
the edges of the chamber, which are cooled. As the oil loses energy and
drops back down into the reservoir, a high speed jet of oil molecules
collides with gas molecules from inside the chamber. They are exhausted
by the roughing pump. Advantages of diffusion pumps include the fact
that they have no moving parts and are relatively robust against
failure. However, given the thermal gradient that must be established
and the high temperatures needed to vaporize the oil, they are quite
inefficient. Other disadvantages include inadvertant oxidation of heated
oil by exposing it to atmospheric pressure and possible contamination of
the interior of the chamber by oil.

A cryogenic pump or cryopump is a cylindrical contraption with a large
number of concentric circular plates. These plates are covered with a
material with a high specific surface area such as a zeolite, which
contains nanoscale pores that trap gases by van der Waals forces. When
cooled with liquid helium, a cryopump is capable of adsorbing even the
lowest molecular weight species, including oxygen and nitrogen gases.
The capacity of a cryopump is very low as---unlike a diffusion or
turbomolecular pump---there is no outlet. Therefore, a cryopump will
become saturated nearly instantly after being exposed to atmospheric
pressure.[^12.2.2] In any case, it needs to be **regenerated** every several
days even with normal use. Regeneration involves allowing the pump to
warm to ambient temperature and flowing an inert gas through the pump to
dislodge adsorbed species. The cryopump is then pumped on with the
roughing pump for several hours. After this procedure, the cryopump is
isolated and the liquid helium is recirculated through the system.

A turbomolecular pump---or turbopump---is like a miniature jet engine.
It contains many layers of fans or **stages** that spin up to 90 krpm.
These fans knock gas molecules from one stage to the next until they
exit through the exhaust out the rear. In this type of pumping, a
backing pump is required to reduce the mean free path of molecules to be
shorter than the distance between stages.

[^12.2.1]: One time in grad school, I was charged with sandblasting the
    components of our e-beam evaporator. After I reassembled the
    chamber, I neglected to reconnect the water lines to the hearths.
    Upon opening the chamber after checking to see if it would hold a
    vacuum, 5 inches of water flooded from the chamber onto the floor,
    in close proximity of many high voltage lines connecting the
    equipment. I never told my professor.

[^12.2.2]: I have done this accidentally many times.

The textbook section on spin coating mentions several factors that affect the results:

1. Concentration of the solute
2. Spin speed
3. Volatility of the solvent

For more details, I'd encourage you to review the spin coating section. Is there a specific aspect you're curious about?

#### Section 3: Patterning techniques
Taken together, the techniques of mastering and replication using
electron-beam lithography, photolithography, and thin-film deposition
form the basis of semiconductor manufacturing in industry and
nanofabrication in research laboratories. It may still not be clear
however how these technologies actually yield patterned structures on
silicon (or other) wafers. Once a pattern in a photoresist film is in
place, various approaches can be used to convert this pattern into a
circuit or circuit component. All of these approaches involve using the
resist film as a stencil mask, see Figure (12.7).

(Figure 12.7) 
>>>image(substrate modification.png.0)

### 12.3.1. The resist film as a stencil mask

The openings in a resist film generated by electron beam or
photolithography can be used to deposit or remove material from the
underlying substrate. These processes include lift-off (basically like
spray painting through a stencil and then "lifting off" the stencil),
ion implantation (sort of like lift-off, except that the "spray paint"
penetrates into the substrate), and etching, where some of the
underlying substrate is removed in a pattern defined by the stencil
mask.

#### Lift-off

In a **lift-off** process, a thin film (often PVD-deposited) is
evaporated across the entire substrate. Dissolution of the resist film
releases the evaporated film everywhere except where the evaporated film
made direct contact with the substrate. Sometimes, an **adhesion
promoter**---such as chromium or titanium---must be used for certain
metals---such as gold, silver, palladium, or platinum---to stick to
silicon well enough to survive the lift-off process. For the lift-off
process to work, the solvent must be able to get to the resist film, and
thus a PVD-deposited overlayer which is to be patterned that is too
thick will impede the process. Often, bath sonication is used to
generate enough cracks in the overlayer for the solvent to undercut. If
the resist film is insoluble (as often occurs with negative-tone
photoresist), an underlying resist film called a **lift-off resist** is
used below the thicker resist, whose primary purpose is to protect the
substrate.

#### Ion implantation

Metal-oxide semiconductor field-effect transistors (MOSFETs) typically
require one or more steps of **ion implantation** to **dope** the source
and drain regions of the device. The process of ion implantation is
similar to that of electron beam evaporation, except that it is the ions
themselves which undergo thermionic emission from a heated filament.
Ions are accelerated with energies on the order of of 100-1000 keV. The
energy affects the depth of implantation, which can range from a few
nanometers to a few microns. To reiterate the effect of the process of
**doping**, atoms with fewer valencies than silicon (e.g., boron),
p-dope the semiconductor, while those with more valencies than silicon
(e.g., phosphorous and arsenic) n-dope the semiconductor. Both types of
doping lead to an increase in the overall conductivity and also
influence the formation of depletion layers at p-n junctions in, e.g.,
solar cells.

#### Etching

A third category of modification of the substrate whose pattern can be
dictated by photolithography is **etching**. Whereas deposition of a
thin film by PVD is **additive**, etching is the removal of material in
a **subtractive** process. Etching can be accomplished under either wet
conditions---**wet etch**---or dry conditions---**dry etch**. Wet
etching typically uses some reactive compound dissolved in a solvent.
For example, a typical **etchant** for silicon is potassium hydroxide
(KOH), and a typical etchant for silica---i.e., silicon dioxide---is
hydrofluoric acid (HF). There are recipes for many etchants used for
many different metals. Etchants can be as simple as acetic acid for zinc
or may involve multiple components, such as a mixture of KI and I $_{2}$
for gold.

Can you explain etching, lift-off, and ion implantation

Certainly! These are all methods to modify substrates using resist films as masks:

1. Etching: Removes material from exposed areas using chemicals or plasma.

2. Lift-off: Deposits material, then dissolves resist, leaving material only in exposed areas.

3. Ion implantation: Bombards substrate with ions to change its properties in exposed regions.

#### Section 4: Unconventional methods for lithography
The best possible resolution of photolithography is limited by the
wavelength of light used. In the case of visible and near-ultraviolet
light, the wavelength is much larger than the size of nanoscale features
one wants to make. For example, if you shine light with a wavelength of
600 nm through a stencil mask with circular holes of 100 nm diameter
separated by 100 nm, your image will be a big blur. The mask will block
some of the intensity of the light, but you will get no image. All of
the light waves will diffract as they exit the 100 nm openings in the
stencil and interfere with each other. One of the ways of getting around
this conundrum---which we have already touched on in the context of
imaging---is to not use photons of light. Instead, particles capable of
traveling with a smaller wavelength than light are capable of higher
resolution. Such methods, which use beams of charged particles like
electrons or ions, are used widely in the manufacturing of
semiconductors. For example, electron-beam lithography is the method of
choice for producing masks for photolithography (i.e., mastering).
Another widely used tool is **focused-ion beam (FIB) lithography**. In
FIB lithography, a beam of ions is used to bombard a sample and etch
little bits of it away, like an atomic-scale jackhammer. Alternatively,
the method can be configured to deposit material. In semiconductor
manufacturing, this capability is often used to repair the masks---i.e.,
masters---used in photolithography. In the rest of this chapter, we will
focus on a different type of non-photolithographic processing that uses
not beams of photons or charged particles, but physical contact (Figure
(12.8)).

(Figure 12.8)

### 12.4.1. Contact lithography

To get around the effects of diffraction, researchers have been
interested in alternative methods of lithography that do not require
light. Often, these methods involve physical contact of a stamp or a
stylus with a substrate. Instead of being limited by light, the
resolution of these methods is determined by intermolecular forces and
the inherent "graininess" of matter. These approaches are generally not
used for the fabrication of integrated circuits for computers and mobile
devices. However, they are useful in the research laboratory, and also
commercially in cases where unusual materials must be patterned---e.g.,
microfluidic reactors for drug encapsulation, biomolecular species for
next-generation genetic sequencing, and fabrication of optical storage
media.

#### Lithography using hard stamps

One of the most common types of unconventional nanofabrication involves
various forms of stamping and molding. These stamps or molds have
**relief structures**---or 3D topography---just like conventional rubber
stamps. Such stamps can be made out of either hard or soft materials.
Hard stamps are generally made of quartz, silicon, or glassy polymers.
These stamps can be pressed into a photocurable or thermally curable
polymer.[^12.4.1] Once cured, these polymers take on the inverse relief
structure of the stamp. An advantage of transparent stamps like those
made of quartz is that light can be transmitted through them to cure
photocurable polymers. An example of this type of approach is
exemplified by **step-and-flash imprint lithography (SFIL)**. Optical
storage disks like CDs and DVDs (I know, ancient technologies) are made
using a similar process of injection molding of a thermoplastic into a
mold with submicron relief structures---around 800 nm for CDs and 600 nm
for DVDs---patterned initially by electron beam lithography. In fact,
this technology has been used since the early 1980s!

#### Soft lithography

While manufacturing features on the submicron (almost "nano") scale has
been used for commercial products for decades, the use of hard materials
has limitations. For example, hard materials can generally only be used
to pattern super flat surfaces. That is, the features cannot conform to
micro- or nanoscale roughness, nor can they bend globally to pattern,
e.g., cylindical, spherical, or bent substrates. Additionally, the
stiffness of a hard stamp makes it difficult to **demold** or remove
from the hardened object without damaging the stamp or the product.
Finally, hard stamps are generally made from materials that are
nonporous, and cannot hold onto liquids like a reservoir to make
multiple "prints" from a single inking.

The most common polymers used for soft lithography are silicone
elastomers, such as **poly(dimethylsiloxane) (PDMS)** or just **silicone
rubber**. PDMS has the repeating structure of \[--O--Si(CH$_3$)$_2$--\].
Unlike most common polymers, the backbone of PDMS does not contain
carbon atoms.[^12.4.2] PDMS can be hardened by crosslinking; the crosslinking
reaction can be performed using light, heat, or simply exposure to air.
A common form of PDMS is the silicone caulking used to seal bathtubs.
Unlike caulking, which is a single-component liquid **prepolymer**, the
PDMS most often used in laboratories has two parts: **base** and
**crosslinker**. The reaction involves a **hydrosilylation** reaction
and is activated at moderate heating of 60-80 $^{\circ}$ C. The most
famous type of PDMS is called Sylgard-184, produced commercially by Dow
Corning, which uses a ratio of base:crosslinker of 10:1. Once
cured---i.e., crosslinked---Sylgard-184 has an elastic modulus of  1 MPa
and a hydrophobic surface. It is also sticky due to **viscoelastic
adhesion**[^12.4.3] and is optically transparent. All of these properties
make it useful for a number of applications in nanofabrication.

#### Aside about polymers in manufacturing

Molding and embossing play a special role in nanofabrication. Almost
every plastic object you use every day is molded. There are three types
of polymers that can be molded:

1.  Thermoplastics

2.  Thermosetting polymers

3.  Photopolymers

A **thermoplastic** is a meltable plastic that is poured or injected
while hot into a mold. Once cooled, the solid piece is removed from the
mold. A thermosetting polymer or **thermoset** is liquid at room
temperature and poured into a mold. The mold and prepolymer are then
heated. Heating initiates a crosslinking reaction that hardens the
polymer into a solid. A cool thing about thermosets is that they can't
be re-melted. Instead, at high enough temperatures, they burn. A
**photopolymer** is similar to a thermoset except that instead of heat,
light is used to activate the crosslinking reaction which hardens the
polymer. To let the light in, a mold used must either be transparent all
around or open on top. A good example of the photocrosslinking process
is in dental fillings. First, the dentist applies a paste to the surface
of the tooth needing to be filled. Then, they take a lamp with a
**waveguide**---i.e., a transparent conduit for light---and shine it at
the paste. After a few seconds, the polymer becomes about as hard and as
durable as the rest of your teeth!

#### Replica molding

With that introduction to thermoplastics, thermosets, and photopolymers
out of the way, we can see how they are used in nanofabrication. The
simplest thing you can do with a stamp is to use it to mold liquid
prepolymers. Usually, this stamp is made of PDMS. The use of this stamp
to mold other polymers from liquid precursors is known as **replica
molding**. Replica molding is the use of a patterned stamp---which can
be hard or soft---to transfer patterns into a liquid prepolymer, which
is then hardened by thermoplastic, thermosetting, or photosetting
mechanisms.

The resolution of replica molding can be very good: on par with that of
photolithography. For example, the smallest feature sizes ever
replicated is a single 0.4 nm step edge attributed to the diameter of a
silicon atom. Thus, replicating objects of molecular dimensions, such as
proteins, viruses, and carbon nanotubes is relatively straightforward.
However, the practical resolution for determining patterns of the type
needed to make structures like those found in integrated circuits is not
limited to physics or mechanics, but rather by the technique used to
make the stamp. That is, the technique used for mastering.

Stamps used in replica molding are mastered using either electron-beam
lithography or photolithography. In university settings and R&D labs,
the best resolution is achieved by e-beam lithography. With either
technique, it is the height and spacing of the hardened resist features
after development that define the pattern for the PDMS prepolymer. This
polymer is poured on top of the e-beam patterned substrate (master),
heated, and hardened (i.e., as a thermoset), and then used to create
replicas in other polymers, such as epoxies, acrylates, polycarbonates,
conductive polymers, or even other silicone rubber materials. Note that
the final structure has the same **polarity** as the original master
created by e-beam lithography.[^12.4.4] The PDMS stamp, on the other hand,
has the reverse polarity, because its role is to transfer the pattern
from the master to the replica. The process makes good, efficient use of
materials because one master can produce many stamps, and every stamp
can produce many replicas.

In the early days of molding, it was thought that it could be used to
replace or complement photolithography in many applications in
microelectronics manufacturing. In these cases, hard stamps were used to
avoid deformation of the pattern when used over large (100 cm$^2$)
areas. There are two variants of the process, **nanoimprint
lithography**, which uses heat to cure the polymer and can thus use an
opaque master like etched silicon as the stamp, and **step-and-flash
imprint lithography**, which uses light to harden the replica. In this
process, a transparent stamp like quartz must be used.

Nanoimprint and step-and-flash processes never took off as a replacement
for photolithography in commercial production. The reasons include the
difficulty and expense of registering a physical stamp with preexisting
nanostructures, breakage of and build up of crud on the the microscopic
relief features of the stamp, and the inability of a stamp to squeeze
the liquid precursor out of the spaces between features.[^12.4.5]

#### Microcontact printing

The second major way in which stamps can be used for replicating
nanostructures is by printing physical inks---**microcontact printing**.
These inks can be prepolymers, solutions of small molecules or
biomolecules, or precursors to self-assembled monolayers. Unlike molding
techniques, which work with either hard or soft stamps, microcontact
printing works best with soft ones. The reason is that soft stamp
materials like PDMS are porous on the molecular scale and can be used as
reservoirs for liquids. This way, the stamp can be inked once to
generate several prints.

By far, the most successful demonstrations of microcontact printing
involve the printing of molecular monolayers of either alkoxysilanes on
silicon or alkane thiols on noble metals like gold and silver. The
lateral resolution is thought to be limited by spreading of the
elastomeric features in contact with the substrate and also by diffusion
of vapors into regions of the substrate around the perimeter of contact
with the stamp. If features are too close to one another, they will tend
to bleed together.

Patterning of molecular monolayers can be used for a few major purposes.
The first is to use the monolayers as etch resists to make small
patterns of metal, but this approach is used less frequently than
conventional photolithography followed by lift-off. However, a major way
in which microcontact printing is used not only in the research
laboratory but also commercially is in biotechnology. For example, to
print nucleic acids and proteins directly, or to print molecules used as
binding sites for these molecules. This technique is used widely in the
sequencing of genetic information, as large libraries of nucleic acids
can be deposited on wafers or chips in precise locations. Binding of
complementary DNA bases can be visualized using a variety of techniques
to reconstruct the whole genome.[^12.4.6]

### 12.4.2. Writing using scanning probes

In the field of nanofabrication it is common to take tools used for
imaging and repurpose them for fabrication. Note that electron beam
lithography is essentially a scanning electron microscope, except that
the beam is not used for imaging, but for writing. Even photolithography
uses the principles of optical engineering---lenses, reflection,
projection, etc.---originally developed for conventional microscopy. It
turns out that a creative bit of reengineering can be used to transform
scanning probe microscope tips into something akin to fountain pens and
engraving tools!

#### Dip-pen nanolithography

Just as a silicone rubber stamp can be inked to transfer patterns of
liquid precursors, an atomic force microscope (AFM) tip can be used like
a quill pen. The use of an AFM tip for nanofabrication is called
**dip-pen nanolithography**.[^12.4.7] Inks used have been alkane thiols to
produce self-assembled monolayers in precise patterns, along with
conductive polymers and biomolecules. While a major apparent
disadvantage of this technique is that it is serial and therefore slow,
it can be made parallel by combining many tips into an array.

#### Nanoindentation lithography

In materials science, a common technique to measure the hardness,
plasticity, and elastic rebound of materials is **nanoindentation**.
This approach uses a hard indenter, typically diamond, and presses it
into a sample. The hardness of the material corresponds to the depth of
indentation at a given force as well as the lateral spread of the
material when indented. A related technique is progressive load scratch
testing, which gives you information about the hardness and plasticity,
as well as adhesion, of thin coatings on substrates. Usually, the same
instrument can be used for either nanoindentation or scratch testing.

Both nanoindentation and scratch testing leave markings behind on the
substrate after they have made their measurements. As you can imagine,
researchers have used patterns of these indentations and scratches as
templates to form nanostructures. For example, for permanent information
storage (i.e., dogtags on the nanoscale) and optical metamaterials.

### 12.4.3. Other approaches

#### Drawing

Nanostructures can also be made using techniques familiar to the fiber
and textile industries like drawing, spinning, and extrusion. Drawing is
the process of stretching a molten polymer, metal, or glass. Submicron
fiber diameters can easily be achieved. In fact, if one starts with a
hollow glass tube, heats it up, then stretches it out, the diameter
shrinks dramatically but the hollow passageway---the **lumen**---stays
put! This technique is used widely in the preparation of tips to poke
single cells and get measurements from them. These tips are also used to
inject or remove genetic material. Drawn glass fibers are also used
widely as optical waveguides in research and in fiber optic
communications.[^12.4.8] The production of polymeric fibers can also be
achieved at the interface between two reacting monomer types.[^12.4.9]

#### Spinning

Another way in which copious numbers of fibers can be generated is by
**spinning**. The spinning process resembles the way in which cotton
candy is made, in which a liquid precursor is loaded into a spinneret
and flung around at high speeds inside a chamber. Fibers of various
polymers can be made this way. For especially thin fibers, a related
method---**electrospinning**---can be used. In electrospinning, a
metallic needle (spinneret) is held at a high voltage relative to a
grounded carrier substrate, which when stationary generates mats of
disorderly fibers, or spun, to generate aligned ones. Nanofibers---or,
sometimes, nanowires---produced by electrospinning are potentially
useful for a variety of purposes, including nanowire transistors,
biosensors, and membranes (used for either encapsulation or separation).

#### Extrusion

Nanofibers can also be made by pushing molten polymer through a porous
die, like how spaghetti is made. The advantage of extruded fibers is
that their cross-sections can have any shape, whereas those made by
drawing are typically cylindrical. Extruded nanofibers have potential
uses as platforms for tissue regeneration and drug delivery, among other
applications.

#### Cutting

If you start with a hunk of cheese and you are asked to make a smaller
piece of cheese, you cut a piece off. Similarly, in nanofabrication, it
is possible to use an **ultramicrotome** to cut objects into thin
slabs.[^12.4.10] The repurposing of an ultramicrotome to make nanostructures
is called "nanoskiving."[^12.4.11] It involves the deposition of metal,
polymers, and ceramics onto a substrate which, when sectioned by the
ultramicrotome, form functional structures. For example, a thin film can
be sectioned into long wires. If one sections forests of cylindrical
nanopillars (e.g., of semiconductors, polymers, or metals) one obtains
arrays of nanodisks. Such structures can be used for a variety of
purposes, e.g., for optical metamaterials.[^12.4.12]

#### Self-assembly

In a future world, we wouldn't have to go through the hassle of creating
masks, stamps, and the manufacturing infrastructure needed to make
nanostructures. Instead, we would put all the starting materials in a
pot, stir, and end up with exactly the nanoscale objects we wanted. The
proof of concept for this seemingly magical approach is the existence of
biological organisms. Plants, animals, and other life forms start only
with instructions (in the form of genes, some starting materials, and
access to the environment) and end up as complex multicellular life
forms. On the other hand, human-initiated self-assembly has not achieved
such complexity. However, it has nonetheless led to the production of
many useful materials and structures, see Figure (12.9).

(Figure 12.9) 
>>>image(self-assembly.png.0)

In fact, we have seen several of these structures before: for example,
self-assembled monolayers are used in biotechnology and molecular
monolayers of silanes are used in microfabrication. Similarly, the
structures formed by block copolymers are found throughout the
manufacture of integrated circuits. Vesicles formed from combinations of
amphiphilic molecules and short chains of polymers have been in the news
as carriers of mRNA-based vaccines. Indeed, while nowhere near the
complexity of biological organisms, modern life has been transformed by
these examples of self-assembled nanostructures.

### 12.4.4. 3D printing of nanostructures

#### Subtractive and additive approaches

Standard techniques of nanofabrication, including etching, liftoff, and
photolithography using positive-tone photoresists, are known as
**subtractive** processes. That is, one starts with a solid structure
and then removes unwanted bits, which are usually discarded. Sculpting
in marble by carving is a familiar example of a subtractive method. In
contrast, sculpting using clay or artists' putty is an **additive**
process. With additive processes, one places material bit by bit---only
where it is needed---to build up the structure.

Nowadays, additive processing---or **additive manufacturing**---is
closely related to the technique known as **3D printing**. With 3D
printing, one inputs a computer-generated design into a tool (a 3D
printer), which generates the structure, **voxel by voxel**, in a serial
process.[^12.4.13] The principal advantage of 3D printing compared to
conventional techniques of molding is that it allows for **rapid
prototyping** and customizability. The ability to create load-bearing,
functional, 3D structures from computer drawings is very powerful.
Conventional machining and manufacturing techniques take manual
expertise, time, and capital. Similarly important as rapidity is
customizability. For example, when 3D printing a part, e.g., for a
biomedical implant, one can generate the part from a scan of the
patient's physiology with which the printed part must match. The primary
disadvantage of 3D printing is that it is quite slow (and therefore
expensive) to be used for mass production. That is, there are few rapid,
parallel methods of replication as there are in conventional printing or
molding using a stamp.

#### Extrusion based methods

The first method of 3D printing to achieve widespread adoption is an
extrusion-based method known as **fused filament fabrication**, also
known as **fused deposition modeling**. In this technique, a heated
print head with a small (\<1 mm) aperture moves about a stage,
depositing material in predefined locations on a substrate. After one
layer is complete, the print head is raised and begins to deposit
material on the next layer. The process resembles that of bricklaying,
while the extrusion mechanism is a bit like the deposition of hot glue
from a glue gun. Advantages of such extrusion-based approaches to 3D
printing include the inexpense of the polymeric materials and the scope
of polymers (most thermoplastics can be made to work). Also, the
simplicity of the mechanical parts make maintenance of such systems
relatively easy. Metallic parts can also be fabricated by fused
deposition processes.

#### Stereolithography

In a process resembling the photpolymerization or photocrosslinking of
negative-tone photoresist, light can be focused in liquid prepolymer to
generate a solid structure. This technique is called
**stereolithography** or **SLA**. It is "stereo" because light needs to
be focused at a particular depth in order to generate enough
constructive interference to solidify the polymer. Operationally, the
SLA process resembles fused filament fabrication. As the beam of focused
light is scanned around, an elevator lifts the slowly built piece from
the bath of prepolymer. Advantages of the technique are resolution and
speed, and the fact that it is amenable to elastomeric materials.
Disadvantages include the cost of the resins, the fact that they have to
be photocurable, and the relative complexity of stereolithography
printers and the difficulty of do-it-yourself repairs to these systems,
compared to extrusion-based printers, whose components are simpler.
